content.webTitle: Alastair Campbell on Bill Clinton | Princess Diana | Robin Cook | Paddy Ashdown

fields.headline: Alastair Campbell's thoughts on...
fields.bodyText: Bill Clinton Perhaps no one comes out of Alastair Campbell's book better than Bill Clinton, even as the Monica Lewinsky crisis threatens to force him out of office amid the Starr report. "Considering what was happening around him, he was amazing." Mr Campbell records Mr Blair taking a liberal attitude. "If you looked at any sexual relationship in the context of a report like that, it could be made to look terrible. Likewise, he said, if every conversation you and I ever had was published, we would be dead." Mr Campbell had earlier asked Mr Clinton what it was like having the whole world talking about his sex life. "He said as long as he couldn't hear them all at the same time he could get by." Princess Diana During the mourning, Tony Blair tried to push the monarchy to modernise, Alastair Campbell writes. But Mr Blair found that relations were still difficult. "TB said the royals were very pleased with the help we had given, but whenever he tried to raise any suggestions of future change, the blinds came down. He said they are very different people in a very different age." After news of the death, Mr Blair told Mr Campbell: "People will be in a state of real shock. There will be grief that you would not get for anyone else." Robin Cook Tony Blair was exasperated with Robin Cook on the first day of the Labour government, the diaries record. After being appointed foreign secretary, Mr Cook immediately spoke to the press. "TB said we had to keep a very wary eye on him. 'He is playing the old games.'" And five days later Campbell reports: "GB said Robin was fucking up on Europe." Campbell makes clear he knew about Mr Cook's affair with his secretary, Gaynor, before the News of the World unmasked it in August 1997. But: "A little part of me sensed that he was almost enjoying the fact he was involved in something like this ..." Paddy Ashdown Even after securing a Commons majority of 179, Tony Blair was still looking to merge Labour with the Liberal Democrats. Around the time of the May 1997 election Paddy Ashdown, the then leader, was "not keen", but agreed to a cross-party committee on constitutional reform. Mr Blair still wanted a merger, however. In October 1997 Blair was moving towards an April reshuffle, bringing two Liberals into the cabinet, with a merger after the next election and proportional representation afterwards, "at which point the Tories would be wiped out." But in September 1998 Mr Blair told Mr Ashdown proportional representation could not be delivered in that parliament.
